text: so uh good afternoon uh folks uh the session we're going to be talking about this afternoon is an mpio cloud cluster
bioinformatics summer project uh my name is dougal ballantyne i'm a solutions architect with amazon web
services i'm based in seattle i work a lot on our hpc offerings and capabilities
and i'm going to talk a little bit if my clicker goes forward about file systems on aws what i'm going
to talk about is some of the building blocks that the aws platform offers some of the components you can use some of
the things you need to think about when you're building a file system on aws and then i'm going to hand over to boyd and
brandon and they're going to talk about actually deploying the orange fs file system on aws as part of a larger
project so a little question what file system must you use on aws um i get this
question a lot and and to be honest the answer is the one that meets your needs
there is no file system on aws you must use there's no file system aws that you have to use you use the file system that
makes the most sense for your environment and i cover here sort of a set of questions i expect people to ask
themselves as they're looking at file systems and these questions are relevant if you are doing like instance based
file systems so exe3 xd4 ntfs or moving up into distributed and replicated file
systems as well so you need to really get an understanding of what are you going to do with the file system and how are you going to use the file system
one of the nice things about aws is we offer a whole pile of building blocks so there's lots of different components on
aws from ec2 and then the ebs volumes s3 is also a solution for storing data and
all of these building blocks together help you form a file system and so it's about understanding those building blocks what they deliver how they
perform so you can build the file system that you want i'm going to talk a little bit about the
building blocks we offer today so we have the amazon elastic compute cloud ec2
they range from very small instances all the way up to very large instances our largest storage instance today comes
with 48 terabytes of storage 24 2 terabyte drives they come with lots of rams so you can
do like ram based file systems or have lots of ram in the cache servers different networking capabilities so a
shared network where you're basically sharing the network with other traffic on your instance so if you're serving a lot of content out to clients then
you're going to be sharing that with the traffic to ebs ebs optimize so you can have a dedicated path to the ebs
infrastructure and then we have 10 gigabit networking on our larger instances to enable you to have 10 gigabit ebs and 10 gigabit node
to node we have amazon simple storage service or amazon s3 unlimited capacity you pay for
what you use not what you provision so you can just keep putting objects in and only pay for what's there
web scale when i say web scale i mean it hard it scales horizontally so the more clients the more connections you point
to s3 the more throughput more capacity you're going to get out of it supports some features like lifecycle management
the ability to cycle content out of s3 into glacier or delete content after the
predefined predetermined amount of time
some of the more low-level building blocks in there is the local storage on the instances so i mentioned that a
little bit in the large instance the 48 terabyte but almost all of our instances have different ephemeral storage
available some of them have ssd back storage some of them have hard drives attached to them and each one you can
choose will deliver a different amount of storage and also performance it takes too long here in the talk to go
through each individual one but we cover them on our website and also it's worth benchmarking each instance to work out
the right one for your application um they are free in the sort of sense of the term it's included in the instance
cost so when you provision the instance the storage is going to be there amazon elastic block store one gigabyte
to a thousand gigabytes of storage standard and provision diops standard volumes deliver about a hundred
iops per second provisioned iops up to four thousand iops on a volume now and
you can choose how many iops each volume needs and configure them appropriately to build out larger environments you can
have multiple volumes on an instance and you can snapshot these volumes into s3 and when you snapshot a volume into
s3 you can recreate that volume in any other availability zone within the region and even copy those snapshots to
other regions to recreate storage solutions in another part
we have a dedicated set of storage optimized instances today these are the hi1 and hs1
instances hi1s are ssd based so we have two terabytes of ssd and the hs1s are direct
attached hard drive instances so 48 terabytes of storage we have ebs optimized instances i
touched upon those earlier these are critical when you're building an environment where you don't want to have
any contention on the storage network for the volumes you've provisioned
so the four questions i like to ask when i'm trying to put these building blocks together is temporary or long-term
storage am i going to store it you know just for the duration of the the simulation or the cluster run or is this
something i need to keep for a very long time maybe i need to keep it for regular reasons is it going to be shared storage that
everyone's going to be using or is it just the instances or the servers who need to have storage for them to be able to compute
how much storage do i need and how fast
so long term storage typically long storm storage we storage we address with amazon s3
you can pull the data sets from s3 whenever you need them so this enables you to build on-demand clusters
on-demand file systems pooling the data sets down from s3 where you've got long-term storage at low cost and onto a
file system you've deployed like orange fs you can easily do it with aws cli this
is a new cli we launched about two months ago and now enables you to do simple bash scripts or incorporate them
into your workflows to do aws cli s3 cp and then pointed a bucket or a file
system and it will copy the data backwards and forwards using multiple threads and multiple streams so you get the most utilization of your bandwidth
and we touched upon it earlier life cycling glacier temporary storage um if you need
temporary storage for your simulation the first place to look always is the ephemeral storage on the instances the
storage is going to go away if the instance goes away so it by definition is temporary building out a distributed file system
on top of ephemeral storage enables you to have a shared scratch file system and a couple of products we list here
orangeyfest we're talking about today lustre ceph and there's lots of other file systems you can deploy on top of
those they give you the ability to take that ephemeral storage and scale it up so there's more
and when working with this you can pull the data down again from aws amazon's storage service and when you pull that
data down you can then use it for the cluster how much um these are just some pointers
when thinking about how much with s3 you're only paying for what you use so you don't really need to think about how
much it's going to be you know when will i access it how long do i keep it with ebs you want to make sure you're only
provisioning the volumes you need so you're going to pay for the storage supervision so you should only provision
you know 10 terabytes if you need 10 terabytes of data
the how fast question so ephemeral storage is always going to deliver more
throughput than the ebs storage or the other storage solutions put together because it's directly attached to the
instances on our high storage instances you can deliver up to 2.2 gigabytes of storage
throughput sequential io on ebs you can deliver a lot more iops and so there's times where you want to
use ebs over the ephemeral storage because it's going to deliver more iops
and with amazon s3 it scales horizontally so if you have hundreds or thousands of clients needing to access
data s3 is going to be able to scale to that without you having to adjust anything in the back end
making those file systems persistent so if you are using some of those file systems which are scratch based or you
want to have some data persistence over a failure look to using ebs block storage or ebs snapshots or the
replication in some of the file systems like gluster fs
and i'm going to talk a little bit about automating deployments so we're going to talk about it in the talk afterwards but cloudformations is a
templating language from aws that enables you to define what a file system or an architecture you want to deploy
looks like so utilizing cloud formations you can make up a file system architecture which is parameterized so
number of storage servers number of volumes and then only adjust the parameters to still deploy the same file
system makes it easy to set them up and tear them down introducing the concept of on-demand file systems and you can
also track any changes to your templates in a source code management system like git or svn so you know what version of
the template is being used by what team or what person
